Subject: New NEAT Paper
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Some of you may have read our previous Tech Report, "Competitive
Coevolution through Evolutionary Complexification."  That paper has
now been replaced with a much-updated journal paper in the Journal of
Artificial Intelligence Research (JAIR), by the same title.  The newer
paper has been expanded and updated, and includes significantly more
experimental results.  Those interested in the relationship between
complexification and the arms race of competitive coevolution may find
the new paper worth a look:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:jair04

The complete paper announcement sent out by JAIR follows (note the
paper is available through several sources now since JAIR is an online
journal):

JAIR is pleased to announce the publication of the following article:

Stanley, K.O. and Miikkulainen, R. (2004)
  "Competitive Coevolution through Evolutionary Complexification", 
   Volume 21, pages 63-100.

   For quick access via your WWW browser, use this URL:
     http://www.jair.org/abstracts/stanley04a.html

Abstract:
Two major goals in machine learning are the discovery and improvement
of solutions to complex problems.  In this paper, we argue that
complexification, i.e. the incremental elaboration of solutions
through adding new structure, achieves both these goals.  We
demonstrate the power of complexification through the NeuroEvolution
of Augmenting Topologies (NEAT) method, which evolves increasingly
complex neural network architectures.  NEAT is applied to an
open-ended coevolutionary robot duel domain where robot controllers
compete head to head.  Because the robot duel domain supports a wide
range of strategies, and because coevolution benefits from an
escalating arms race, it serves as a suitable testbed for studying
complexification.  When compared to the evolution of networks with
fixed structure, complexifying evolution discovers significantly more
sophisticated strategies.  The results suggest that in order to
discover and improve complex solutions, evolution, and search in
general, should be allowed to complexify as well as optimize. 

The article is available via:
   
 -- comp.ai.jair.papers (also see comp.ai.jair.announce)

 -- World Wide Web: The URL for our World Wide Web server is
       http://www.jair.org/
    For direct access to this article and related files try:
       http://www.jair.org/abstracts/stanley04a.html

 -- Anonymous FTP from Carnegie-Mellon University (USA):
        ftp://ftp.cs.cmu.edu/project/jair/volume21/stanley04a.ps
    The compressed PostScript file is named stanley04a.ps.Z 

For more information about JAIR, visit our WWW or FTP sites, or
contact jair-ed@...
